text: Your body contains enough iron to forge a metal nail about 3 inches long.
Vitamin D levels affect over 1,000 different genes in your body, impacting everything from immune function to mood.
Your blood travels about 12,000 miles daily through your circulatory systemâ€”nearly half the Earth's circumference.
Cortisol, often called the "stress hormone," naturally peaks in the morning to help you wake up.
A single drop of blood contains approximately 5 million red blood cells.
High-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP) can detect inflammation at levels 1/1000th the concentration of traditional tests.
Adults generate about 2-3 million new red blood cells every second.
Your cholesterol levels can vary by up to 10% depending on whether you're standing or lying down during the blood draw.
Hemoglobin A1c provides a three-month average of your blood glucose levels, while a standard glucose test only shows a moment in time.
The human body produces about 1-1.5 quarts of saliva daily, which contains important biomarkers for disease detection.
Your resting heart rate is typically lower in the morning and can increase by 10-15 beats per minute after a meal.
Ferritin levels can be up to 10 times higher in men than in women due to menstruation-related iron loss.
Your gut microbiome contains trillions of bacteria that produce biomarkers reflecting your overall health.
Blood pressure naturally dips by 10-20% during sleep in healthy individuals, a pattern called "nocturnal dipping."
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels fluctuate throughout the day, typically highest at night and lowest in the afternoon.
Dehydration of just 1-2% can decrease cognitive function by up to 10%.
Over 50% of the calcium in your bloodstream is bound to proteins and doesn't show up in ionized calcium tests.
Your body has enough DNA that, if stretched end to end, would reach from Earth to the Sun and back over 600 times.
Vitamin B12 levels can remain normal for years even with severe deficiency due to large liver storage reserves.
A high-sensitivity troponin test can detect heart muscle damage at concentrations 1/1000th of what older tests could identify.
The average adult has about 1.2-1.5 gallons (4.5-5.5 liters) of blood circulating in their body.
Testosterone levels in men naturally decline by about 1% per year after age 30.
Your lungs contain approximately 300 million tiny air sacs (alveoli) with a total surface area roughly the size of a tennis court.
Homocysteine levels can increase by up to 10% after just one cup of coffee.
The electrical signals from your heart are about 60 times stronger than those from your brain.
Fasting for just 12 hours can increase human growth hormone (HGH) production by up to 1,300%.
White blood cells make up less than 1% of your blood but are crucial for immune response.
Uric acid, which can indicate gout risk, naturally varies by up to 20% throughout the day.
Your body's pH is so tightly regulated that a change of just 0.5 units can be life-threatening.
Magnesium is involved in over 300 enzymatic reactions in your body but is rarely measured in standard blood tests.
